title: Privacy and Schizophrenia

content: Many people and their families are hesitant to openly share their diagnosis of schizophrenia due to the stigma against mental health conditions and the need to protect themselves.

The typical stereotype of someone with schizophrenia paints a bleak picture. Often, it’s associated with violence and harming others around them. For some, that may be close to reality, but it’s far from the truth for others. There is a broad spectrum. Regardless of the severity and symptoms, privacy typically allows individuals to live without fear of being judged, scrutinized, or attacked.

Everyone has the right to decide if, what, and when as it relates to disclosing their health information, as well as who has access to it. It’s a tough decision to be open about schizophrenia. Should I protect myself from potential prejudice and discrimination, or would I get more help and support by sharing?
Here are some of my lessons learned.

The first people I told about my condition were close friends and family, with whom I already had trusted personal relationships. They stood by me throughout my schizophrenia journey and offered a helping hand, i.e., going to the doctor with me, making sure I had dinner, visiting me in the hospital, etc.

The first people I told about my condition were close friends and family, with whom I already had trusted personal relationships. content: Next, I was fortunate to find a psychiatrist and therapist to talk to comfortably. With them, I could freely communicate my thoughts without fearing negative consequences. The doctor made sure I was prescribed the proper medication and monitored biometrics. Paired with medicine, regular time with my therapist gave me a safe space to focus on my thoughts that I might otherwise not express openly.
Outside of close friends, family, and health care professionals, there are support groups that we can contact and join that have communities of people with similar experiences or who can help.
For me, I had decided early on during my recovery period that I would share my experience openly. Some of the benefits I realized from sharing include:
Freedom of expression and mental well-being. It was easier not to have something bottled up inside. I was relieved to be able to speak to my close friends.

sections.heading: Learning from others' experiences.
content: Several people have written books about their lived experiences with mental health conditions. I found it helpful to read about others and learn to avoid common mistakes and potential mis-care.

sections.heading: Friends and family catching the symptoms earlier.
content: Knowing what I have, my friends, family, and caregivers keep a close eye on me and help me address any new flare-ups during my maintenance period.

Ultimately, the more we share and discuss (only when individuals are comfortable with it), the more we can fight stigma through proper education and learning and stop people from being afraid of people like me.
Just remember: We are more than this brain disease.
